title: Srimad Bhagavatam | HG Madhu Pandit Dasa | SB 3.20.37 | 23-02-2016
speaker: HG Madhu Pandit Dasa

segments.key_quote: Asuras are described as Mudadhya, meaning they are captivated by ignorance.
segments.summary: The speaker explains that Asuras are captivated by ignorance and are foolish because they are attracted to the illusory attractions of the material world.

segments.key_quote: One gives experience of gold, the other one is real gold and real gold also gives experience of gold but it has also got the value of gold that is a difference.
segments.summary: Using the analogy of real gold versus plated gold, the speaker explains the difference between experiential truth and existential truth, highlighting that true value lies in something being both experientially and existentially true.

segments.key_quote: To establish the existential truth of something, any amount of experiences with the senses will not determine that truth. One has to go beyond the senses and go to the intelligence.
segments.summary: The speaker asserts that sensory experience alone cannot establish existential truth; one must go beyond the senses to intelligence and spiritual knowledge (Guru, Sadhu, and Shastra).

segments.key_quote: There is only way to establish whether an experience is existentially true or not, is by a third source, that is Shastra.
segments.summary: The speaker emphasizes that Shastra is the only reliable source for determining whether an experience is existentially true, as our senses are prone to illusion.

segments.key_quote: The person is influenced by only experience, not using the intelligence.
segments.summary: The speaker uses the analogy of buying gold-plated items to illustrate how those who rely solely on sensory experience, without using intelligence, can be easily cheated.

segments.key_quote: Among the illusions, again there is filter, what is permitted by the shastras.
segments.summary: The speaker explains that while all sense experience in the material world is illusion, a devotee filters experiences through the lens of the shastras, engaging in authorized sense gratification, which is better than being an Asura.

segments.key_quote: Soul is not directly feeling anything in this world.
segments.summary: The speaker explains that those seeking ultimate truth understand that experiences are generated by the material body, mind, and intelligence, while the soul merely observes, identifying with the feelings of the 'yantra' (machine).

segments.key_quote: In the same way, in this material world, maya is expert, expert like a jeweler who cheats. She is expert. Her job is to duplicate the gold of the spiritual world here.
segments.summary: The speaker compares Maya to a jeweler who expertly duplicates gold, creating illusions of thinking, feeling, and willing, just as the soul does, to deceive people in the material world.

segments.key_quote: Similarly, the shastra says that all beauties in this world is only skin deep.
segments.summary: The speaker describes the body as a leather bag containing a complex mechanism (yantra) duplicated by Maya, emphasizing that worldly beauty is only skin deep.

segments.key_quote: We create in our mind illusion. And that mannequin, that fiberglass doll is just a trigger in your mind.
segments.summary: Using the analogy of a mannequin in a saree shop, the speaker explains how Maya duplicates names, forms, and qualities, triggering desires and illusions in our minds, leading us to paste our identity onto the body.

segments.key_quote: Krishna consciousness is meant to take us out of this bodily concept of life and come into spiritual concept of life.
segments.summary: The speaker explains that we live in a bodily concept of life, residing in the subtle body, and Krishna consciousness aims to shift us to a spiritual concept of life, realizing ourselves as spirit souls with the potential for a sacchidananda body.

segments.key_quote: Unless and until we start seeing people differently, we will also be in the bodily concept of life.
segments.summary: The speaker emphasizes that spiritual progress requires changing our perception, seeing people not as bodies but as conscious souls, understanding that the body is merely a neutral extension of the pancha bhuta (five elements).

segments.key_quote: So that's why maya has created this body, so all quality should appear.
segments.summary: The speaker explains that Maya has created the body to duplicate the qualities of the soul (thinking, feeling, willing), leading to the illusion of identifying with the body and its characteristics, such as being male or female.

segments.key_quote: To say that I am a male is first illusion, to say that I am a female is another illusion.
segments.summary: The speaker clarifies that attraction between male and female is based on the false ego and illusory self-concept, originating from the body rather than the soul.

segments.key_quote: Not at all easy, but it is very easy if we associate with the holy name.
segments.summary: The speaker states that overcoming illusion is difficult but can be made easier by associating with the holy name, which is the source of true knowledge and allows us to see with the eyes of intelligence rather than being deceived by Maya's expertise.

segments.key_quote: But I cannot see what my eyes sees, I should see what my shastra tells to see.
segments.summary: The speaker emphasizes the importance of seeing through the lens of shastra, recognizing that the material world is skin deep and that the soul is often haunted by a bodily concept of life, leading to a replacement of identity.

segments.key_quote: This ghost, comes into the body, enjoys, afterwards it goes away.
segments.summary: The speaker compares false ego to a ghost that temporarily possesses the body for sense gratification, only to disappear later, leaving the 'normal self' to question the indulgence.

segments.key_quote: I am a person, capable of thinking, feeling and willing. I am not a male person, I am not a female person, I am a person.
segments.summary: The speaker advises disassociating from the concepts of male and female, focusing on being a person capable of thinking, feeling, and willing, and ultimately identifying as a servant of Krishna, utilizing the body in His service, which is the essence of Bhagavad Dharma.
